spans.content: emitters for silicon heterojunction solar cells
Abstract A method for the deposition of molybdenum oxide
with high growth rates at temperatures below
based on plasma- enhanced atomic layer deposition is presented. The stoichiometry of the overstoichiometric
films can be adjusted by the plasma parameters. First results of these layers acting as hole- selective contacts in silicon heterojunction solar cells are presented and discussed.
Its spectrally broad transparency and high work function make evaporated molybdenum oxide

a promising candidate for substituting amorphous silicon emitter in silicon heterojunction (SHJ) solar cells [1]. Thus, the replacement of the p- doped amorphous silicon emitter by higher band gap materials like
can lead to a gain in the photocurrent of such cells [2, 3]. However, a thin

intrinsic amorphous silicon ((i)a- Si:H) layer between the oxide and the crystalline silicon (c- Si) is still needed to improve the poor surface passivation quality of the oxide and to fully benefit of the
Although the hole- selective conductivity mechanism through the
stack is not fully understood in detail, it is influenced by the defect state density in the
conformal oxides on structured silicon surfaces, atomic layer deposition (ALD) is due to its reaction- limited growth process an ideal candidate [5]. Thermal ALD recipes for
are recently reported by different groups, but up to now none of these
layers are tested as emitter alternative in SHJ solar cells [6- 8].
In this work, we introduce an alternative new plasma- enhanced atomic layer deposition (PE- ALD) process for
layers. Influences of the process conditions on the stoichiometry of these layers as well as their performance on cell level are shown.

The thicknesses and growth per cycle (GPC) of the produced

layers on silicon substrate are measured by spectral ellipsometry using a Tauc- Lorentz model combined with an Gauss oscillator to model sub- band- gap absorption if necessary [9]. X- ray photoelectrons spectra of the as- deposited
layers are measured by a Kratos Axis Ultra photoelectron spectrometer (X- ray source Al
For the solar cell preparation, polished float- zone- grown phosphorous- doped (100) silicon wafers with a resistivity of
were used. The wafers were cleaned using the RCA process and dipped in diluted hydrofluoric acid (2 min,
vol.) prior to amorphous silicon depositions, and
intrinsic amorphous silicon was deposited at the front side of the wafers, and a stack of
phosphorous- doped amorphous silicon was deposited on the back side.
Amorphous silicon layers were deposited by plasma- enhanced chemical vapor deposition. The intrinsic amorphous silicon layers were deposited using an excitation frequency of
, the distance between electrode and substrate on the grounded electrode was
, and the process gas consisted of pure silane. The intrinsic layers were exposed to a hydrogen plasma treatment [10] in the same reactor at
and a plasma power density of
Phosphorous- doped amorphous silicon was grown in a reactor with
with a gas- phase doping of
provided by mixing phosphine diluted at
Directly after a 1- min dip in
vol. diluted Hf, to remove an potential native oxide from the amorphous silicon, 10- and

- thick molybdenum oxide layers have been deposited by the introduced PE- ALD processes with varying plasma steps on the front side of the wafers. Following the molybdenum oxide depositions, indium tin oxide (ITO) was sputtered onto the samples. The ITO layers were RF- sputtered from a ceramic target at a pressure of
. The sputter gas consisted of argon with
oxygen for the front side ITO and
oxygen for the back side layer. The thickness of the front side ITO is about
was deposited on the back side. Since the layers were deposited at room temperature, a two minute post- deposition anneal at
Metal contacts were applied by thermal evaporation of titanium silver stacks. Ten nanometer of titanium was deposited as an adhesion layer, and
of silver was added on the back side and
on the front side. The front side evaporation was conducted through a shadow mask. Afterwards, the solar cell area of
was defined by photolithography and HCl etching of the ITO layer on the front side.
Photoconductance decay measurements were conducted using a Sinton Instruments system to measure the minority
carrier lifetime of the wafers in between different process steps [11]. Bright IV of the solar cells was measured using a class c sun simulator.
film thickness determined by spectral ellipsometry, plotted over the number of performed ALD cycles for the 1- second and 2- second
plasma processes, is shown. A very similar linear increase in layer thickness with number of cycles is found for both processes. The relatively high growth rate per cycle of
plasma durations indicates that oxygen saturation is reached at a plasma power of
is one main benefit compared to the thermal ALD
process reported by Bertuch et al. [8], who use the same Mo precursor but ozone as oxidant. For the thermal ALD
is reported. By PE- ALD, the activation energy can be delivered by the oxygen reactants from

plasma. This enables higher growth rates especially for lower deposition temperatures. The growth rates are not significantly influenced by longer purge times or by the integration of an additional Ar plasma step in the cycle, like its done on the process 2- second
The optical parameters, estimated from the ellipsometry data of the different
layers, are slightly affected by the duration of the plasma step (compare Fig. 5). While the 2- second
plasma process shows no subband- gap absorption, the additional argon plasma step
leads to small, wide sub- band- gap absorption in the
plasma duration, the subband- gap absorption is more pronounced and less wide (Fig. 5).
thickness measured by spectral ellipsometry data plotted versus the number of ALD cycles
X- ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to identify the core level binding energies and oxidation states of the

layers. The spectra of the films on silicon show characteristic peaks for the oxygen molybdenum. Beside a small carbon peak from surface contamination, no additional peaks can be found in the survey spectra (not shown). In Fig. 6, very similar spectra for all processes can be found in the Mo3d doublet region. Two peaks are observed at 232.5 and

A clear difference can be found in the O 1s energy region in Fig. 7. While all measurements show a similar O
a second oxygen- related peak at higher binding energies can be found in the spectra. In the 1- second
is less pronounced, compared with the spectra of 2- second
processes, in which this peak is located at slightly higher binding energies at
.Chot and coauthors [12] assign a very similar peak in molybdenum oxide to strongly absorbed oxygen as

Although we cannot exclude that this peak is formed by adsorbed air moisture in the layers, as samples were not transferred in vacuo to the spectrometer. It is very likely that this difference is process related, in particular because the samples have been produced after each other and transferred together. It seems plausible that a longer oxygen plasma step leads to a higher content of strongly absorbed oxygen in the
layers itself. However, a stoichiometry analysis of the measured XPS spectra shows over- stoichiometric
for all produced layers. While the O to Mo proportion
layer, a higher oxygen content is measured for 2- second
Fig. 8 Solar cell results plotted versus
induced dark band bending above: high work function
- thick oxide layers in SHJ solar cells. The cell results (compare Fig. 8) show significant differences mainly in the open- circuit voltage. While the oxides grown in the 2- second
values reach by the oxides grown in the 1- second

. It is worth mentioning that the low open- circuit voltages in these cells are not limited by enhanced surface recombination. From lifetime measurements of the samples after ITO sputtering and post- anneal (not shown), a quasi- Fermi level splitting at 1 sun (often called implied
could be measured for all samples. Both processes without Ar plasma step tend to slightly lower open- circuit voltages for thicker oxide layer. Cells with
layers grown in a process with Ar plasma step show an opposite trend.
The parasitic absorption in the thin oxides is not the only optical loss, shadowing of the ITO itself, as well as
differences in the reflection of the front side stacks are also limiting the current. Therefore, the cells with thin
oxide layers show very similar currents. A loss in current by doubling the oxide thickness can be seen in all produced cells. As expected the 1- s
layers show the highest optical loss, by doubling the layer thickness, above
. Although the extinction coefficient, determined by spectral ellipsometry on as- deposited oxide layers, is slightly higher for the

process with Ar plasma step, the short- circuit currents do not reflect such tendencies. This could indicate that the ITO sputtering step and the post- deposition anneal determine the optical properties of the

layers. The fill factors and efficiencies of all cells are limited by differently strongly pronounced s- shape in the bright IV curves (compare Figs. 10, 11). Bataglia et al. [3] have reported similar "s- shape" feature, more pronounced for thicker evaporate
layers of SHJ solar cells with
emitter. Same tendencies can be found here for cells with

layers grown in PE- ALD process without additional Ar plasma step. One possible reason for such shape could be the existence of a large barrier for hole transport in SHJ solar cells with sufficient front surface passivation [13]. At first sight, it seems plausible to assume that an insufficient hole transport through the
layers itself is the dominating part of such barrier in the produced cells. The decrease in fill factor for thicker oxide layer seems to support this idea. Anyhow,

layers grown in PE- ALD process with additional Ar plasma step do not show such dependency. On the other hand, the valence band offset on the a- Si:H/c- Si interface could be the dominating part of the barrier, if a tunneling process of holes through this offset is dominating the current a wider barrier leads to a more pronounced s- shape. The width of such barrier is
Fig. 10 Bright IV curves of SHJ cells with
Fig. 11 Bright IV curves of SHJ cells with
working point dependent and directly influenced by the band bending. A lower work function of the
would introduce a lower dark band bending in the c- Si (see schematic sketch in Fig. 9).
Therefore, a lower open- circuit voltage, and as well as more pronounced "s- shape" can be expected. In total, it leads to a significant loss in fill factor and efficiency.
It is known that work function in sub- stoichiometric molybdenum oxide

decrease by the removal of oxygen [14]. Although all as- deposited oxides are overstoichiometric, we speculate that the ITO sputter step and the post- deposition anneal can reduce the oxygen content in the
layers during the cell process. It might be somehow plausible that after these reductions the
layers with initial less oxygen still have a lower content and therefore a lower work function compared to layers with higher initial oxygen content. Such an effect would explain the high decrease in
and fill factor seen in cells with
PE- ALD process, with lower initial oxygen content.
A new PE- ALD process for the deposition of
with high growth rate at temperatures below
has been presented. XPS measurements show that the stoichiometry of the grown oxides can be influenced by the duration of the oxidizing plasma step. In a first experiment, the integration of these
layers as alternative emitters in SHJ solar cells are tested with efficiencies above
influence of initial stoichiometry on the open- circuit voltage and on cell performance can be reported. The best cells have a
layer and a 2- second oxygen plasma step.
